candidates.title: Use 32‑bit floats by default for HNSW vector indexes
candidates.body:
Thank you for submitting this pull request. We really appreciate you spending the time to work on SurrealDB. 🚀 🎉 

## What is the motivation?

When defining an HNSW vector index without explicitly specifying a vector type, the system previously defaulted to 64‑bit floats. This is atypical for embedding workloads (which almost always use 32‑bit floats), wastes memory, and can be surprising for users who expect `F32` semantics. This change makes the implicit default match common practice and the expectations of users working with embeddings.


## What does this change do?

- Changes the default `VectorType` from `F64` to `F32` for vector indexes in both the catalog schema and SQL layer.
- Updates the `DEFINE INDEX ... HNSW DIMENSION ...` parser so that, when no explicit vector type is given, it now assumes `VectorType::F32` instead of `VectorType::F64`.
- Adjusts language tests for search fusion functions (`search::linear` and `search::rrf`) so that the expected distances and combined scores match the new default floating‑point behavior (slight numeric differences and cleaner, non‑"almost" values for linear scores).
- No changes are required to user queries or schemas that already specify a vector type explicitly; the impact is on the implicit default only.
  
## What is your testing strategy?

- Rely on the updated language tests:
  - `crates/language-tests/tests/language/functions/search/search-linear.surql`
  - `crates/language-tests/tests/language/functions/search/search-rrf.surql`
  to validate distance calculations and fusion scores under the new default.
- Run the existing core test suite for index definitions and SQL parsing to ensure the new default integrates cleanly with the catalog and parser layers.
- Perform a manual smoke test by:
  - Defining an HNSW vector index without specifying a type.
  - Inserting a small set of vector records.
  - Running k‑NN and combined search queries to confirm they execute successfully and return stable, sensible scores with the new `F32` default.

candidates.title: Expose cancellation token in datastore initialization API

labels.name: topic:surrealkv
labels.description: This is related to the SurrealKV storage engine

candidates.body:
Thank you for submitting this pull request. We really appreciate you spending the time to work on SurrealDB. 🚀 🎉 

## What is the motivation?

The datastore initialization previously lacked a way for applications to signal graceful shutdown or cancel long-running operations during startup. This made it difficult to implement proper cleanup and cancellation semantics when shutting down servers or stopping database connections cleanly. By exposing the cancellation token through the initialization API, consumers can now propagate cancellation signals from the application level down into the datastore layer.

## What does this change do?

This PR adds a `CancellationToken` parameter to the datastore initialization chain:

- **Core API changes**: Updates `TransactionBuilderFactory::new_transaction_builder()` and all `Datastore::new*()` methods to accept a `CancellationToken` parameter
- **Server integration**: The server's existing cancellation token (created in `cli/start.rs`) is now passed through to datastore initialization, enabling coordinated shutdown behavior
- **Backward compatibility**: The `Datastore::new()` convenience method automatically creates a new token internally, maintaining a simple API for basic use cases
- **Dependencies**: Adds `tokio-util` as a dependency to provide the `CancellationToken` type
- **Documentation**: Adds comprehensive parameter documentation explaining the cancellation token's purpose

The change follows the thread from server startup (`cli/start.rs`) → database initialization (`dbs/mod.rs`) → datastore factory (`kvs/ds.rs`), allowing the cancellation signal to reach all backend implementations.

## What is your testing strategy?

- **Unit tests updated**: All existing datastore tests in `kvs/tests/mod.rs` have been updated to pass `CancellationToken::new()` for all backend types (memory, RocksDB, SurrealKV, TiKV)
- **Integration verification**: The server initialization flow passes the actual cancellation token used for coordinating shutdown across all components
- **Existing test coverage**: All existing tests continue to pass, verifying that the API changes don't break functionality
- **Manual testing**: Server startup and graceful shutdown should be tested to ensure the cancellation token properly propagates through the initialization chain

candidates.title: Remove FoundationDB storage engine
candidates.body:
Thank you for submitting this pull request. We really appreciate you spending the time to work on SurrealDB. 🚀 🎉 

## What is the motivation?

FoundationDB has been extracted to a [separate repository](https://github.com/surrealdb/surrealdb-foundationdb) to simplify the core SurrealDB codebase and address several operational challenges:

#### Build Complexity and Dependencies

- Local Installation Requirement: Building with FoundationDB support requires the FoundationDB client library to be installed locally, adding complexity to the build environment and CI/CD pipelines
- Native Dependency Chain: The `foundationdb` crate pulls in significant native build dependencies including `bindgen`, `clang-sys`, and platform-specific compilation requirements
- Development Friction: Contributors and users need to install and maintain FoundationDB infrastructure just to build the project, even if they don't intend to use this storage engine

#### Transaction Limitations

FoundationDB imposes strict transaction constraints that can impact SurrealDB workloads:

- 10 MB Transaction Size Limit: Each transaction is limited to 10 MB of data, which can be restrictive for batch operations, large document imports, or complex queries that touch many records
- 5 Second Transaction Duration: Transactions must complete within 5 seconds by default, though this can be configured up to 5000ms in our implementation. Long-running analytical queries or bulk operations may hit this limit
- Retry Complexity: While FoundationDB provides automatic retry mechanisms, these add complexity to transaction handling and can mask underlying performance issues

#### Architectural Considerations

- Separate Binary Required: FoundationDB integration now requires using `surreal-fdb` binary instead of the standard surreal binary, as it lives in a separate repository
- Composable Architecture: The new composable datastore pattern means FoundationDB is better maintained as a separate crate that composes with `surrealdb-core` rather than being tightly coupled
- Reduced Core Complexity: Removing FoundationDB from the core reduces the maintenance burden and testing surface area for the primary storage engines

## What does this change do?

Removes FoundationDB as a built-in storage engine from the core codebase.

- [x] No related issues

- [ ] Documentation needs updating

candidates.title: Pin `hyper`, `ort`, and `ort-sys` dependencies to prevent build breakage
candidates.body:
Thank you for submitting this pull request. We really appreciate you spending the time to work on SurrealDB. 🚀 🎉 

## What is the motivation?

Running `cargo update` currently breaks the build due to incompatibilities between newer versions of certain dependencies and SurrealML. Specifically, newer versions of `hyper` (>1.6.0) and `ort`/`ort-sys` (>2.0.0-rc.9) introduce breaking changes that cause compilation errors. This prevents developers from safely updating dependencies and maintaining a healthy dependency tree.

## What does this change do?

This PR pins three critical dependencies at the workspace level to prevent automatic updates that would break the build:

- **`hyper`**: Pinned to `=1.6.0` to maintain compatibility with current server implementation
- **`ort`**: Pinned to `=2.0.0-rc.9` to ensure SurrealML continues to function correctly
- **`ort-sys`**: Pinned to `=2.0.0-rc.9` to match the `ort` version requirement

The changes consolidate dependency management by:
- Moving `hyper` from a direct dependency in `crates/server/Cargo.toml` to a workspace-level dependency
- Adding explicit workspace references for `ort` and `ort-sys` in the server crate with documentation explaining the version constraint

## What is your testing strategy?

- Verify the project builds successfully with the pinned dependencies: `cargo build`
- Confirm `cargo update` no longer introduces breaking changes by running it and ensuring the build still succeeds
- Run the existing test suite to validate that functionality remains unchanged: `cargo test`

candidates.title: Add missing storage backend features

labels.name: topic:surrealkv
labels.description: This is related to the SurrealKV storage engine

candidates.body:
Thank you for submitting this pull request. We really appreciate you spending the time to work on SurrealDB. 🚀 🎉 

## What is the motivation?

The main `Cargo.toml` was missing feature flags for three storage backends that are already supported in the `surrealdb-server` crate. This prevented users from enabling these storage options when building SurrealDB from the root workspace, creating an inconsistency between available backends and exposed features.

## What does this change do?

Adds three storage backend feature flags to the root `Cargo.toml`:
- `storage-tikv` - Enables TiKV distributed transactional key-value database support
- `storage-fdb` - Enables FoundationDB distributed database support  
- `storage-indxdb` - Enables IndexedDB browser storage support

Each feature flag passes through to the corresponding feature in the `surrealdb-server` crate, following the existing pattern used by other storage backends like `storage-rocksdb` and `storage-surrealkv`.

candidates.title: Fix Number hash to use consistent value hashing.
candidates.body:
Thank you for submitting this pull request. We really appreciate you spending the time to work on SurrealDB. 🚀 🎉 

## What is the motivation?

<!-- Please provide details on the motivation for why you have made this change.-->

Hashing of Number is different for each variant but the `PartialEq` impl evaluates `Int(1)` as equal to `Decimal(1)`. It is undefined behavior when PartialEq evaluates to equal but Hash returns a different value.

## What does this change do?

<!-- Please provide a description of what this pull request does, and how it solves the problem. -->

This change modifies the current hash implementation of Number to use the consistent lexicographic hashing used for storekey values. Now `1f`, `1dec`, and `1` evaluate as the same hashed value in a set.

## What is your testing strategy?

<!-- Write your test plan here. Please provide us with clear instructions on how you verified your changes work. -->

Updated the language tests.

candidates.title: Extract server implementation into surrealdb-server crate
candidates.body:
Thank you for submitting this pull request. We really appreciate you spending the time to work on SurrealDB. 🚀 🎉 

## What is the motivation?

This refactoring improves the architectural separation between the core SurrealDB library and server-specific functionality. By extracting server components into a dedicated crate, the project achieves:

- **Clearer boundaries**: Core database logic is separated from HTTP/WebSocket server, CLI, and network infrastructure
- **Better modularity**: Users of the SurrealDB library (via SDK) are not forced to pull in server dependencies like Axum, Tower, CLI tooling, and telemetry infrastructure
- **Improved maintainability**: Server-specific features can evolve independently from the core library
- **Supply chain security**: Isolates server-specific dependencies to reduce the attack surface for embedded library users

## What does this change do?

This change introduces a new `surrealdb-server` crate that consolidates all server-related functionality previously scattered in the root crate:

**Moved Components:**
- **CLI tooling** (`cli/`): Command-line interface for start, import, export, SQL shell, ML operations, and validation
- **Network layer** (`net/` → `ntw/`): HTTP/WebSocket endpoints, authentication, middleware, headers, and routing (renamed to `ntw` for supply chain tooling compatibility)
- **RPC layer** (`rpc/`): HTTP and WebSocket RPC protocol implementations
- **Telemetry** (`telemetry/`): Metrics, traces, logs, and OpenTelemetry integration
- **GraphQL** (`gql/`): GraphQL endpoint implementation
- **Server initialization** (`dbs/mod.rs`): Database bootstrap and server-specific startup logic
- **Configuration** (`cnf/`, `env/`): Server configuration and environment handling

**Architectural Changes:**
- Root `src/main.rs` reduced to a 15-line binary entry point that delegates to `surrealdb_server::init()`
- Root `Cargo.toml` simplified by ~154 lines, moving server-specific dependencies (Axum, Clap, Tower-HTTP, Tracing-subscriber, OpenTelemetry, Rustyline) to the server crate
- Server crate provides features for storage backends, scripting, HTTP, ML, and allocation tracking

## What is your testing strategy?

- All existing integration and unit tests should continue to pass, ensuring the refactoring maintains functional parity
- Server functionality tests in `crates/server/src/` verify CLI, network endpoints, and telemetry work correctly

candidates.title: Fix SELECT with SPLIT so ORDER BY and START/LIMIT apply after splitting
candidates.body:
Thank you for submitting this pull request. We really appreciate you spending the time to work on SurrealDB. 🚀 🎉 

## What is the motivation?

Queries that use `SPLIT` on array fields and also specify `ORDER BY` and/or `START … LIMIT …` could return incorrect or truncated results. The root cause was that ordering/limit optimizations and pagination were effectively applied before the `SPLIT` expansion finished, so rows created by `SPLIT` were miscounted or misordered.

## What does this change do?

 Ensures the execution pipeline expands rows via `SPLIT` before applying `ORDER BY` and pagination. The effective order is now: iterate → SPLIT → GROUP (if any) → ORDER BY → START/LIMIT → FETCH.
- Disables the `ORDER BY … LIMIT …` priority‑queue optimization when a `SPLIT` clause is present, because `SPLIT` changes the result cardinality; this prevents early trimming that would drop valid rows.
- Result: `SELECT … SPLIT … ORDER BY … START … LIMIT …` now yields correctly ordered, correctly paginated rows from the fully expanded set.

Relevant implementation spots for reviewers:
- `crates/core/src/dbs/iterator.rs`: `output_split` is executed before `sort` (ORDER BY) and `start_limit`.
- `crates/core/src/dbs/result.rs`: `Results::prepare` skips the `MemoryOrderedLimit` optimization when `stm.split().is_some()`.

## What is your testing strategy?

Language tests:

- Single value split with random ordering:
  - `SELECT * FROM t SPLIT a ORDER BY rand()` returns one row when `a = [1]`.
- Multiple rows expanded by `SPLIT`:
  - `SELECT * FROM t SPLIT a` yields all split elements across records, preserving element order per record.
- Deterministic order across split rows:
  - `SELECT * FROM t SPLIT a ORDER BY id` returns all rows ordered by `id` after splitting.
- Correct pagination after splitting and ordering:
  - `SELECT * FROM t SPLIT a ORDER BY id START 1 LIMIT 2` returns the 2nd and 3rd rows from the ordered, fully expanded set.
- Regression around optimization:
  - Verify that with `SPLIT` present, no early `ORDER BY … LIMIT` trimming occurs (row counts and contents match expectations).
  - Verify that without `SPLIT`, the existing `ORDER BY … LIMIT` optimization continues to work and yields identical results.


## Is this related to any issues?

candidates.title: DB-417: Memory‑bounded LRU cache for HNSW vectors; remove deprecated MTREE index
candidates.body:
Thank you for submitting this pull request. We really appreciate you spending the time to work on SurrealDB. 🚀 🎉 

## What is the motivation?

The previous in‑memory storage for HNSW vectors grew with workload and could retain data after index/table removal, increasing the risk of excessive memory usage or OOMs on large datasets or multi‑tenant deployments.
- Users need predictable memory consumption for vector search, and operators need a single, tunable limit.
- MTREE vector search has been deprecated for some time; keeping it adds maintenance overhead and user confusion.

## What does this change do?

Introduces a memory‑bounded LRU cache for HNSW vectors:
  - Implemented in `crates/core/src/idx/trees/hnsw/cache.rs` using `quick_cache` with a custom weighter that accounts for the actual memory size of each `SharedVector` and its key `(TableId, IndexId, ElementId)`.
  - Eviction lifecycle hook keeps a per‑index set of cached element IDs in sync so we can bulk‑evict efficiently.
  - Integrated at the store layer (`crates/core/src/idx/trees/store/mod.rs`) and within HNSW elements (`crates/core/src/idx/trees/hnsw/elements.rs`) to transparently cache on read and write, and to purge on element/index removal.
  - Configurable cache size via `SURREAL_HNSW_CACHE_SIZE` (default: 256 MiB) defined in `crates/core/src/cnf/mod.rs`.
- Removes the deprecated MTREE vector search implementation from the codebase.

User impact:
- HNSW vector search uses a bounded memory cache by default, reducing memory spikes and improving stability under load.
- No query syntax changes. Operators can tune memory via `SURREAL_HNSW_CACHE_SIZE`.
- MTREE index type is no longer available (it was deprecated); users should use HNSW for vector search.


## What is your testing strategy?

- Functional correctness
  - Cache hit/miss path: `get_vector` returns from cache when present; on miss, loads from KV, re‑caches, and returns the same distance results as before.
  - Forced eviction: run with a very small `SURREAL_HNSW_CACHE_SIZE` to trigger evictions; verify no panics, and subsequent queries re‑load from KV correctly.
  - Insert/remove lifecycle: inserting vectors adds them to the cache and per‑index tracking; removing an element or dropping an index/table evicts all tracked entries for that index (assert empty tracking set afterward).
  - Concurrency: parallel inserts/reads simulate query load; ensure no deadlocks and consistent results.
- Regression/parity
  - Run existing HNSW language tests (e.g., `crates/language-tests/tests/language/statements/define/index/multiple_hnsw.surql`) and ensure identical query results.
  - Run HNSW benchmarks (`crates/sdk/benches/index_hnsw.rs`) to confirm performance remains stable or improves due to caching.
- Configuration
  - Verify `SURREAL_HNSW_CACHE_SIZE` is honored: with different sizes, observe expected eviction frequency and bounded memory usage.
- Upgrade check
  - Verify that creating/using HNSW indices works as before, and that MTREE types are not accepted/advertised anymore (clear error or removal from docs/DDL if applicable).

Acceptance criteria:
- HNSW ANN queries return correct results with or without cache hits.
- Memory usage remains within the configured budget under sustained load.
- Dropping an index/table fully clears any cached vectors for that index.
- No references to MTREE indexing remain; users can only define and use HNSW for vector search.

candidates.title: SDB-17: Ensure all statements return a value.
candidates.body:
Thank you for submitting this pull request. We really appreciate you spending the time to work on SurrealDB. 🚀 🎉 

## What is the motivation?

<!-- Please provide details on the motivation for why you have made this change.-->

It is currently very hard to predict how many results will be returned in a query because of the following:

1. `OPTION`, `BEGIN`, `CANCEL`, and `COMMIT` do not return anything.
2. If there’s a `RETURN` statement between a `BEGIN` and `COMMIT` only that one statement is returned. But if there are no `RETURN` statements then all statements will have return values.

## What does this change do?

<!-- Please provide a description of what this pull request does, and how it solves the problem. -->

This change updates `OPTION`, `BEGIN`, `CANCEL`, and `COMMIT` to always return `NONE`.

All statements between a `BEGIN` and `COMMIT` now return a value unless they’re explicitly placed within a block.

## What is your testing strategy?

<!-- Write your test plan here. Please provide us with clear instructions on how you verified your changes work. -->

Language tests.

candidates.title: Migrate RocksDB dependency to published crates.io package
candidates.body:
Thank you for submitting this pull request. We really appreciate you spending the time to work on SurrealDB. 🚀 🎉 

## What is the motivation?

The project was depending on a git repository reference for RocksDB (`surrealdb/rust-rocksdb.git`), which introduces several challenges:
- Git dependencies make builds slower and less reproducible
- They complicate version management and dependency resolution
- Security auditing tools prefer published packages from crates.io
- Users downstream can't easily inspect or verify the exact dependency versions

## What does this change do?

his PR migrates the RocksDB dependency from a git repository reference to a published crates.io package:
- **Dependency update**: Replaces `rocksdb` git dependency with `surrealdb-rocksdb` version `0.24.0-surreal.1` from crates.io
- **Package renaming**: Updates package names from `rocksdb`/`librocksdb-sys` to `surrealdb-rocksdb`/`surrealdb-librocksdb-sys` across security configurations
- **Security audit updates**: Refreshes supply-chain configuration to track the new published packages
- **Maintained compatibility**: Preserves the same RocksDB version (10.6.2) and features (lz4, snappy compression) with SSTFileManager bindings included

The published package includes the SSTFileManager bindings that provide control over disk space usage, which were added in PR #6530.


## What is your testing strategy?

- **Existing test suite**: All existing RocksDB-related tests run automatically with the new package, validating functional equivalence
- **Build verification**: CI builds ensure the new package compiles correctly across all supported platforms
- **Integration testing**: The RocksDB storage backend is exercised through SurrealDB's comprehensive test suite, covering database operations, transactions, and disk management
- **Dependency audit**: Supply-chain tools verify the package authenticity and security posture

## Is this related to any issues?

Relates to #6530

candidates.body:
Thank you for submitting this pull request. We really appreciate you spending the time to work on SurrealDB. 🚀 🎉 

## What is the motivation?

<!-- Please provide details on the motivation for why you have made this change.-->

There has been a long-running desire to be able to execute client-side transactions from the SurrealDB SDKs.

## What does this change do?

<!-- Please provide a description of what this pull request does, and how it solves the problem. -->

1. **New RPC Methods**: Adds `begin`, `commit`, and `cancel` methods to the RPC protocol for explicit transaction lifecycle management
2. **Transaction Storage**: Implements transaction storage using UUID-keyed maps in both WebSocket and Local engine contexts, allowing transactions to persist across multiple operations
3. **Transaction Context**: Extends the query execution path to accept transaction UUIDs, enabling operations to execute within an existing transaction context rather than creating new ones
4. **SDK Transaction API**: Enhances the SDK's `Transaction` object to act as a fully-functional database client - all standard methods (create, select, update, delete, query, etc.) can be executed within the transaction scope
5. **Protocol Support**: Implements support for WebSocket and Local/embedded connections; HTTP protocol explicitly does not support client-side transactions and returns `MethodNotFound`

candidates.body:
Thank you for submitting this pull request. We really appreciate you spending the time to work on SurrealDB. 🚀 🎉 

## What is the motivation?

The current RocksDB implementation can fail abruptly when disk space is exhausted, leading to database unavailability. This creates operational challenges where users cannot recover from disk space issues without external intervention. The change addresses this by implementing proactive space management that allows the database to continue serving read operations and enable space recovery through deletions, providing a more graceful degradation path instead of complete failure.

## What does this change do?

This PR introduces an SST file manager that monitors disk space usage and implements a state machine with two operational modes:

- **Normal mode**: All operations (read, write, delete) are permitted
- **Read-and-deletion-only mode**: Only reads and deletes are allowed; writes are blocked

**Key features:**
- Configurable space limit via `SURREAL_ROCKSDB_SST_MAX_ALLOWED_SPACE_USAGE` environment variable (default: 0/unlimited)
- Automatic transition to read-and-deletion-only mode when SST file space reaches the configured limit
- Warning at 80% space utilization to provide early indication of approaching limits
- Allows deletions even in restricted mode, enabling users to free space and recover
- Automatic compaction after deletion-only transactions to reclaim space immediately
- Automatic recovery to normal mode when space usage drops below the limit
- Transaction-level validation that checks mode state at commit time, handling long-running transactions that span mode transitions
- Replaces reactive out-of-disk error handling with proactive space management

**Implementation details:**
- `DiskSpaceManager` tracks SST file sizes in real-time using RocksDB's `SstFileManager` API
- Disables RocksDB's built-in hard limit to allow application-level control
- Transaction operations (`set`, `put`, `putc`) use `ensure_write()` which validates the mode state
- Delete operations (`del`, `delc`) use `ensure_deletion()` which permits deletions in both modes
- Error type changed from `DbReadOnly` to `DbReadAndDeleteOnly` with user-friendly messaging
- **RocksDB version bump**: Upgrades from 10.4.2 to 10.6.2 through a forked rust-rocksdb crate, enabling access to required `SstFileManager` and `Env` APIs


#### Automatic Recovery
**No restart required!** When you delete enough data and the database size drops below the configured limit, the database automatically returns to normal mode and write operations resume. This happens seamlessly without any manual intervention.

#### Technical Improvements
- Uses RocksDB's SST File Manager API for accurate, real-time space tracking
- Implements a state machine that transitions smoothly between normal and restricted modes
- Centralized validation logic ensures consistent behavior across all database operations
- Comprehensive test coverage for the new functionality

#### User Benefits
- **Avoid service disruptions**: Graceful degradation instead of hard failures
- **Self-healing**: Automatic recovery when space is freed - no restarts needed
- **Stay in control**: Delete data to recover without external intervention
- **Early warning**: Get notified before hitting the limit
- **Production-ready**: Thoroughly tested and integrated into CI

## What is your testing strategy?

Comprehensive integration test (`read_and_deletion_only.rs`) that validates the complete state machine behavior through five phases:

1. **Normal operation**: Verifies writes work before reaching the limit
2. **Mode transition**: Writes data until space limit is reached and confirms write operations start failing with appropriate errors
3. **Read-and-deletion-only validation**: 
   - Confirms new write transactions are rejected
   - Verifies uncommitted transactions from before the transition are rejected on commit
   - Validates read operations continue to work
   - Confirms delete operations are permitted
4. **Space recovery**: Deletes data to free space below the limit, triggering compaction
5. **Normal mode recovery**: Verifies write operations are automatically re-enabled after space recovery

The test uses environment variables to control space limits and flush behavior, simulating realistic disk pressure scenarios with approximately 20MB of test data against a 10MB limit.

candidates.title: Prepare SurrealDB for Java SDK v3.0 compatibility
candidates.body:
Thank you for submitting this pull request. We really appreciate you spending the time to work on SurrealDB. 🚀 🎉 

## What is the motivation?

The main motivation for this PR is to enable the Java SDK to work properly with SurrealDB 3.0 by making the core library more language-agnostic and exposing necessary APIs for external language bindings.

### Key Issues Being Addressed:

1. **JavaScript Feature Lock-in**: The `surrealdb-types` crate was being compiled with the `js` feature flag enabled in the core, which forced JavaScript-specific dependencies to be included even when using non-JavaScript language bindings like Java. This created unnecessary dependencies and potential conflicts for other language SDKs.

2. **Missing Public API**: The `IntoVariables` trait, which is essential for implementing query variable binding in external language bindings, was not publicly exposed. This prevented the Java SDK from properly implementing variable binding functionality for parameterized queries.

## What does this change do?

This PR makes two minimal but critical changes to enable Java SDK compatibility:

### Change 1: Remove JavaScript feature from surrealdb-types
**File**: `crates/core/Cargo.toml`
- **Before**: `surrealdb-types = { workspace = true, features = ["js"] }`
- **After**: `surrealdb-types = { workspace = true }`

**Impact**: Removes the JavaScript-specific feature flag from the types dependency, making the core types crate language-agnostic. This ensures that JavaScript-specific dependencies (the `js` crate) are not forced upon other language bindings, reducing unnecessary dependencies and potential conflicts for SDKs in other languages.

### Change 2: Expose IntoVariables trait publicly
**File**: `crates/sdk/src/method/mod.rs`
- **Before**: `pub use query::{Query, QueryStream};`
- **After**: `pub use query::{IntoVariables, Query, QueryStream};`

**Impact**: Makes the `IntoVariables` trait publicly accessible from the SDK's method module. This trait is essential for converting types that implement `SurrealValue` into `Variables` for query binding. By exposing it publicly, external language bindings (like the Java SDK) can now properly implement and use variable binding when executing parameterized queries.

## What is your testing strategy?

N/A

candidates.title: Support multi-session support in RPC protocol

labels.name: needs-documentation
labels.description: Needs documentation to be added and tracked before merge

candidates.body:
Thank you for submitting this pull request. We really appreciate you spending the time to work on SurrealDB. 🚀 🎉 

## What is the motivation?

<!-- Please provide details on the motivation for why you have made this change.-->

#6440, #2338

## What does this change do?

<!-- Please provide a description of what this pull request does, and how it solves the problem. -->

This PR introduces a new `session` property on RPC messages. It accepts a UUID, and when provided with one the server will use the session associated with that UUID or create a new one.

When calling the `reset` method with a session id provided, it will remove that session and clear out any live queries associated with it.

when no session id is provided, a default session will be used. Nothing changes on that front.

This PR also introduces a `sessions` RPC method. The primary session always exists, but this method will return a list of uuids representing all the various sub sessions that exist

candidates.title: Async configuration validation for startup: make `ConfigCheck` async and composable
candidates.body:
Thank you for submitting this pull request. We really appreciate you spending the time to work on SurrealDB. 🚀 🎉 

## What is the motivation?

Many real‑world deployments need to validate configuration by calling external systems before the server starts, for example:
- Checking authentication/authorization setup with a remote service
- Verifying a license or cloud entitlement
- Performing an online version or compatibility check
- Validating secrets/keys stored in a remote KMS

## What does this change do?

- Converts the `ConfigCheck` trait to async and adds platform‑appropriate bounds:
  - `ConfigCheck::check_config(&mut self, cfg)` → `async fn check_config(&mut self, cfg)`
  - Introduces `ConfigCheckRequirements` to express bounds differently on native vs WASM targets.
    - Native: `Send + Sync + 'static`
    - WASM: no `Send` requirement
- Updates the CLI startup path to await the async check.
- Re‑exports `ConfigCheckRequirements` so embedders can implement it.
- Adds the `async-trait` dependency to support async traits across targets.

## What is your testing strategy?

Github action - existing test should suffice
